document.docAuthor: Chandra, Kailash, Singh, Navneet, Kumar, Vikas, Ranjan, Rahul, Caleb, John T. D., Gayen, Subrata, Das, Moumita & Dey, Rushati
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Mustilizans Yang, 1995 (Lepidoptera: Endromidae) in India with the description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Mustilizans Yang, 1995 (Lepidoptera: Endromidae) in India with the description of a new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Mustilia hepatica Moore, 1879
, Lep. Coll. late Mr Atkinson : 82, pl. 3: fig. 18.

Mustilia columbaris Butler, 1886
, Proc. Zool. Soc. London : 387, pl. 35: fig. 7.

Type material :
Holotype male:
India
: West Bengal : Darjiling (=Darjeeling), deposited in ZMHUB (color photo examined).

Holotype male of
Mustilia columbaris
from Murree (presently in Pakistan ) deposited in BMNH (color photo examined).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6. Adults of
Mustilizans
spp. 1,
M. hepatica (Moore)
, holotype (male), Darjeeling; 2,
M. columbaris Butler
(male), Murree, Pakistan; 3,
M. hepatica aeola Zolotuhin
(male), Changwat Nan, Thailand; 4,
M. hepatica Moore
(male), Arunachal Pradesh, India; 5,
M. zolotuhini
sp. n.
, holotype (male), DDBR, Arunachal Pradesh, India; 6,
M. zolotuhini
sp. n .
, paratype (male), DDBR, Arunachal Pradesh, India. Scale bars: (2–6), 1 mm. Photo credits: Figs 1–3, Dr. V. V. Zolotuhin.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The species
M. hepatica Moore
is better diagnosed from its male genital attributes and is closely related to
M. dierli Holloway. In
M. hepatica
, the uncus is bifurcated with a shallow groove, apices are short and rounded whereas, in
M. dierli
apices of the uncus are very long and slender; in
M. hepatica
sacculus of valva is smooth whereas in
M. dierli
, sacculus is with teeth on the inner edge; in
M. hepatica
, cuiller bears numerous, thin and straight setae, whereas in
M. dierli
, cuiller bears short and curved setae. Other closely related species of
M. hepatica
is
M. zolotuhini
,
sp. nov.
The diagnostic differences of both the species are discussed under the diagnosis of the latter.

Remarks. A single specimen identified as
M. hepatica
was examined from Arunachal Pradesh , India . It shows variation in the coloration: the forewing coloration is darker, rusty-brown almost uniformly whereas the type specimen is distinct greyish-cream colour (cf. Fig. 1 with Fig. 4 ). The wingspan measures up to 62 mm measuring the largest in the range for the species. The male genitalia ( Figs. 7–11 ), however, are matching with the illustrations of Zolotuhin (2007) .
